-	Each of the four HP Suction Scrubbers, 19-1289, 19-1291, 19-1293 & 19-1295, has a design liquid volume of 588 gallons (14 bbl) of NGL/MI @ 5.33 lb/gal and 59% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) = 1,850 lbs. each
Additional NGL/MI volume is available in the system through the associated process piping.  This additional volume for the Gas Handling/ Gas Injection Process portion of the NGL/MI Process is estimated to be 60% of the total vessel volume (122,007 gallons), which is approximately 73,205 gallons (1,743 bbl) @ 5.33 lbs/gal and 59% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) = 230,205 lbs.
The total NGL/MI in the Gas Handling/ Gas Injection Process is approximately 195,210 gallons (4,648 bbl) @ 5.33 lbs/gal and 59% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) = 614,000 lbs.
Stabilization Process
-	Both Stabilizers, 19-1102 & 19-1152, have a design liquid volume of 7,435 gallons (177 bbl) of NGL/MI @ 5.33 lb/gal and 59% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) = 23,000 lbs. each.
-	Both Stabilizers Reboilers, 19-1315 & 19-1365, have a design liquid volume of 17,900 gallons (426 bbl) of NGL/MI @ 5.33 lb/gal and 59% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) = 56,300 lbs. each.
-	The Stabilizer Overhead Drum 19-1206 has a design liquid volume of 12,010 gallons (286 bbl) of NGL/MI @ 5.33 lb/gal and 59% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) = 38,000 lbs.
-	Both LP Suction Scrubbers, 19-1207 & 19-1257, have a design liquid volume of 1,555 gallons (37 bbl) of NGL/MI @ 5.33 lb/gal and 59% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) = 5,000 lbs. each.
-	Both Blowcases, 19-1208  & 19-1258, have a design liquid volume of 715 gallons (17 bbl) of NGL/MI @ 5.33 lb/gal and 59% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) = 2,000 lbs. each.
-	The NGL Divert Tank 19-1233 has a design liquid volume of 63,340 gallons (1,508 bbl) of NGL/MI @ 5.33 lb/gal and 59% by weight

The Central Gas Facility (CGF) is classified as NAICS code 211111, Crude Petroleum and Natural Gas Production.  A Program 1 plan for both the propane refrigeration process and NGL/MI process is being submitted.

Description of  stationary source and regulated substances handled:
CGF is located west of the Central Compression Plant (CCP) in the East Operating Area (EOA). The purpose of CGF is to increase overall field production of Greater Prudhoe Bay. Raw gas is received from the Gathering Centers and Flow Stations at approximately 550 psig and 70°F to 75°F. It is routed through inlet separators at both the CCP and CGF. The inlet separators remove any remaining moisture, crude products, triethylene glycol (TEG) carryover, and any other remaining contaminants. After inlet separation, all of the gas is routed through CGF where the raw gas pressure is boosted to approximately 700 psig in three Booster Compressor trains to increase the efficiency of the three Low Temperature Separation (LTS) trains that separate the heavier Natural Gas Liquids (NGLs) and Miscible Injectant (MI) products from the lighter residue gas (primarily methane). The dry residue gas is compressed by the CGF Tandem Compressors and the CCP compressors to be reinjected into the gas cap while the heavier NGL and MI products are further processed in the Stabilization System. The Stabilizer uses a fractional distillation process to separate the valuable NGLs from the MI gas. The NGLs are shipped to the pipeline and the MI gas is compressed for injection into the oil bearing formation to enhance the oil production. 

During peak years of production at Prudhoe Bay, CGF processed up to 9.3 Bscfd of gas, producing up to 101,000 bpd of NGL product and up to 612 MMscfd of MI product. Current production rates (as of 2012) are well below those peak values, but typically are in the range of approximately 7.5 Bscfd of gas, 55,000 bpd of NGL and 235 MMscfd of MI product.

Propane Refrigeration and Manufacturing Sy

stem

CGF utilizes propane in a refrigeration system.  The propane refrigeration system is a closed circulating loop.  Liquid propane is generally manufactured at CGF, stored in the 19-1218 refrigerant storage drum and added as make-up to the 19-1216 surge drum as needed.  The propane refrigerant system includes the following equipment and approximate inventories:
-	The 19-1218 refrigerant storage drum provides liquid propane storage for make-up. The storage drum has a design liquid volume of approximately 124,351 gallons (2,961 bbl) @ 4.23 lbs/gal = 525,000 lbs.
-	The 19-1216 refrigerant surge drum provides liquid propane storage. The surge drum contains approximately 32,050 gallons (763 bbl)@ 4.2 lbs/gal = 134,610 lbs.

An economizer system facilitates compression of propane refrigerant in multiple stages, which improves overall system efficiency:
-	The LP economizer has a design liquid volume of approximately 12,100 gallons (288 bbl) @ 4.2 lbs/gal = 50,820 lbs.
-	The HP economizer has a design liquid volume of approximately 15,290 gallons (364 bbl) @ 4.2 lbs/gal = 64,220 lbs.
-	Four chillers (19-1310, 19-1360, 19-1386-A and 19-1386-B) allow for heat exchange between incoming process natural gas and propane refrigerant. The total design volume for all four chillers is approximately 64,880 gallons (1,540 bbl) @ 4.2 lbs/gas = 271,660 lbs.
-	The LP Suction Drums (19-1211 and 19-1261) are for final liquids gravitational separation from gaseous propane before compression.  The Suction Drums have a total design liquid volume of approximately 12,520 gallons (298 bbl) @ 4.2 lbs/gal = 52,580 lbs.
-	The De-ethanizer and De-propanizer equipment in the propane manufacturing process have a combined design liquid volume of approximately 1,722 gallons (41 bbl) @ 4.2 lbs/gal = 7,230 lbs. 

Additional propane volume is found in the system through the associated process piping.  This additional volume is estimated to be 60% of the total vessel volume (259,700 gallons), which is app

roximately 155,820 gallons (3,710 bbl) @ 4.2 lbs/gal = 654,445 lbs.
Total propane inventory onsite is approximately 420,000 gallons (9,900 bbl) @ 4.23 lb/gal = 1,800,000 lbs.

The refrigerant storage drum is located along the West edge of the CGF facility pad, slightly North of center.  This orientation provides for better potential dispersion from bimodal Southwest/Northeast winds.

Catastrophic loss of inventory of the 19-1218 refrigerant storage drum and subsequent vapor cloud explosion (VCE) to the 1 psi endpoint is the basis for the Worst Case Scenario calculations.  The model used was a TNT Equivalent Calculation in RMP*Comp.

Gas Handling/Gas Injection and Stabilization Processes

Natural gas is routed to low-temperature processing where it is chilled using the propane refrigeration process to extract NGLs for use as MI.  The mixed NGL, comprised primarily of liquid hydrocarbons in propane (C3) through pentane (C5) range, is a regulated flammable substance.  The quantity of NGL/MI stored and in process at CGF consists of the following equipment and approximate inventories:
	
Gas Handling/ Gas Injection Process
-	The Inlet Separator 19-1237 has a design liquid volume of 6,175 gallons (147 bbl) of NGL/MI @ 5.33 lb/gal and 59% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) = 19,400 lbs.
-	The Portatest has a design liquid volume of 760 gallons (18 bbl) of NGL/MI @ 5.33 lb/gal and 59% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) = 2,400 lbs.
-	Both LT Separators, 19-1101 & 19-1151, have a design liquid volume of 41,370 gallons (985 bbl) of NGL/MI @ 5.33 lb/gal and 59% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) = 130,000 lbs. each.
-	Both LTS Reboilers, 19-1308  & 19-1358, have a design liquid volume of 12,050 gallons (287 bbl) of NGL/MI @ 5.33 lb/gal and 59% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) = 38,000 lbs. each.
-	Each of the four LP Suction Scrubbers, 19-1288, 19-1290, 19-1292, & 19-1294, has a design liquid volume of 1,470 gallons (35 bbl) of NGL/MI @

Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) = 199,000 lbs.
Additional NGL/MI volume is available in the system through the associated process piping.  This additional volume for the Stabilization Process portion of the NGL/MI Process is estimated to be 60% of the total vessel volume (130,560 gallons), which is approximately 78,335 gallons (1,865 bbl) @ 5.33 lbs/gal and 59% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) = 204,600 lbs.
The total NGL/MI in the Stabilization Process is approximately 208,900 gallons (4,973 bbl) @ 5.33 lbs/gal and 59% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) = 656,900 lbs.
The total NGL/MI onsite inventory (combined Gas Handling/Gas Injection and Stabilization Processes) is approximately 404,110 gallons (9,622 bbl) @ 5.33 lbs/gal and 59% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) = 1,270,000 lbs.

Catastrophic loss of inventory of the NGL Divert Tank 19-1233 and subsequent vapor cloud explosion (VCE) to the 1 psi endpoint is the basis for the Worst Case Scenario calculations for the NGL/MI processes. The model used was a TNT Equivalent Calculation in RMP*Comp.

Other Information Required Per 40 CFR 68.155:

CGF's accidental release prevention and emergency response policies are predicated on compliance with OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) standard.  The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps include process hazard analysis (PHA) and layer of protection analysis (LOPA).  The facility has had no accidents in the past five years from covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.  The emergency response program was developed consistent with OSHA's Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response (HAZWOPER) and PSM standards, as well as other applicable regulations.  Planned changes to improve safety occur through the incident investigatio

n process, closure of PHA recommendations, and regularly scheduled safety meetings.  

Enclosed modules which house process equipment operated at CGF are equipped with fire suppression systems.  In the event of fire, HalonA1 fire suppressant is automatically released to inhibit the chemical reaction of combustion and extinguish the flames.  

Prudhoe Bay has its own professionally-trained fire department which responds and serves as the local fire department.  There is no other jurisdiction providing emergency response at CGF, with the exception of mutual aid provided by the fire departments of other nearby North-Slope Alaska oil fields.
